STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 12, 2023
Ciara Johnson
Wayne County DHHS – North Central
8625 Greenfield, Rd.
Detroit MI, 48228-2224
RE: License#: CP820201495
Dear Ms. Johnson:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201495
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Ciara Johnson
Name of Agency: Wayne County DHHS – North Central
Agency Address: 8625 Greenfield Rd
Detroit, MI 48228-2224
Agency Telephone #: 3138521709
Original Issuance Date: 09/20/1993
License Effective Date: 12/29/2021
License Expiration Date: 12/28/2023
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 11/15/23, 11/16/23, 11/2/23, 11/21/23,11/23/23,
11/30/23, 12/1/23
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 72 4
Homes pending licensure 26 4
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 14 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 46 6
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 26 6
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 1 1
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 321 8
Children discharged from care during this period 47 6
Youth in independent living placement N/A N/A
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection N/A N/A
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection N/A N/A
Open child adoption cases N/A N/A
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 60 10

Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1

Supervisory Staff 3
Administrative Staff 5

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 72 4
Unlicensed relative homes 88 5
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 4
Foster Children 18
Relatives 5
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
2 of 19 employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One new employee record showed the employee's six-month’s evaluation
was due by 10/17/2023 and completed on 11/3/2023.
• A second employee record showed the employee’s annual evaluation was
due by 8/30/2023 and completed late on 9/8/2023.
Repeat Violation cited during the November 2022 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 2/14/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/ agency agreement.
(3) The agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, devleop a new agreement.

1 of 8 open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation that the
foster parent/agency agreement was reviewed with the foster parent during the
foster home’s 2023 annual inspection.
CPA Rule 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall
recommend to the department the issuance of a
regular license or the continuation of an active license
only when all rules are in compliance or both of the
following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been
developed. The plan must comply with all of the
following requirements:
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
In 2 of 6 special evaluations reviewed where a corrective action plan was
required, the record did not show documentation of both foster parents' signature
in that two-parent foster home.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation,
an agency shall complete a written report that includes
all the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included
in the report.
3 of 6 special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of all places of
contacts, nor that all persons interviewed were documented in the methodology
section of the report.
Repeat Violation cited during the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
(5) Before the placement of a child, the agency shall
document preparation of all relevant parties, including
the child or infant, which must include an explanation of
all the following:

(a) The circumstances necessitating placement.
(b) The child's individual needs.
(c) Any special problems presented.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)-(c) as
required by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
2 records did not show compliance:
• In 1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed where the child was replaced
on 9/7/2023, the record did not show documentation of (e) as required by
the rule.
• In another where the child's case was reported as closed and the child
returned from an out of state placement in June 2023, the record did not
show documentation of (e) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (f)
related to the child's 9/7/2023 replacement.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care
up to the time of the change in placement and
the needs that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.

3 of 6 closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a) and
(b) as required by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
Sub-Section-Description 2
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of
the last physical examination.
2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child's initial medical was due by 4/16/2023 and
was completed 18 days late on 5/4/2023.
• A second record did not show documentation of an initial medical for the
child after initial placement on 3/10/2023. The record showed a prior
10/3/2022 emergency room visit, which indicated it was not intended as a
well child examination.
Repeat Violation cited during the November 2022 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 2/14/2023; and the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed showed the child's dental was due by
5/15/2023 and was completed five days late on 6/20/2023.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
(d) Any know history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement.
2 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance related to (c)-
(g):
• One record did not show verification that the child’s caregiver was provided
this information at the child's initial placement.
• A second record did not show verification that the information was
provided to the child's caregiver related to the child's 4/5/2023, 4/20/2023
and 5/19/2023 replacement.
Repeat Violation cited during the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
4 of 7 initial service plans were late by:
• 2 days.
• 5 days.
• 15 days.
• 19 days.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.

3 of 12 updated service plans (related to 3 of 8 open foster child records
reviewed) were late:
• One child's 7/15/2023-10/12/2023 USP was completed 4 days late.
• A second child's 4/21/2023-7/19/2023 USP was completed 6 days late.
• A third child's 7/29/2023-10/26/2023 USP was completed 5 days.
Repeat Violation cited during the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
4 of 7 initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as required
by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the
foster parent.
2 of 7 initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of (h) as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation cited during the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.

2 of 12 updated service plans reviewed (related to 1 of 8 open foster child records
reviewed) did not show documentation of (g) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation cited during the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
In 1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed, where siblings were split, the record
did not show documentation a July 2023 sibling visit.
FOM 722- 6B Family team meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward
Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
1 of 19 service plans reviewed did not show documentation of an FTM for the
child’s 4/16/2023-7/14/2023 USP.
Repeat Violation cited during the November/December 2021 Renewal
inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plan.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:

• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
9 of 19 treatment plans reviewed (related to 7 of 8 open child record revoewed)
did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of the caregiver’s signature on the
child’s 8/29/2023-9/27/2023 treatment plan.
• A second record did not show documentation of the caregiver’s signature
on the child’s 4/21/2023-7/19/2023 treatment plan.
• A third record did not show documentation of the caregiver’s signature on
the child’s 6/29/2023-7/28/2023 treatment plan.
• A fourth record did not show documentation of the birth parent’s signature
on the child’s 4/26/2023-5/25/2023 and 5/26/2023-8/23/2023 treatment
plans.
• A fifth record showed the child’s 3/17/23-4/17/23 treatment was not signed
by the caregiver, the document signed 8//3/202 indicated it was provided at
at a home visit. This child’s 4/16/2023-7/14/2023 treatment plan was also
not signed by the caregiver until 9/14/2023.
• A sixth record did not show documentation of the cargeiver signature on
the child’s 6/7/2023-9/4/2023 treatment plan.
• A seventh record did not show documentation of the birth parent’s and
caregiver signature on the child’s 8/29/2024-9/27/2023 treatment plan.
Repeat Violation cited during the November 2022 Interim inspection, with a
CAP approved on 2/14/2023; and cited under 722-8C and ISEP 6.33 during
the November/December 2021 Renewal inspection, with a CAP approved on
12/27/2021.
FOM 801-C Medical passport.
Initial medical passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date
4 of 8 open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:

• 3 records did not show documentation that the caregiver was provided a
copy of the child’s medical passport within two weeks of the respective
child’s 3/17/2023, 5/8/2023, and 6/29/2023 date of placement.
• Another record did not show documentation that the respective caregiver
was given a copy of the child’s medical passport for the child’s three
replacements.
Repeat Violation cited under ISEP 6.49, during the November/December
2021 Renewal inspection, with a CAP approved on 12/27/2021.
SRM 200 Fingerprints.
Personnel Training
All personnel, contractors, vendors, and external
auditors who have access to CW-CHRI are required to
complete Security Awareness Training (SAT). Training
is available on the Learning Management System
(LMS) for MDHHS personnel and contractors with
access to LMS. Non-contracted agencies will complete
Fingerprint Security Awareness Training via the
MDHHS public licensing website.
SAT is required to be taken within six months of
working in a position with CW-CHRI access and every
two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes
SAT timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all
employee personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts
to confirm completion of training
In 1 of 19 employee records reviewed where the employee had access to CHRI,
the record showed the employee’s updated fingerprint awareness training, which
was due by 3/10/2023 was completed late on 4/17/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12209(1) Orientation and training.
• The agency was apprised its proof of orientation shall consistently document
the dates the specific training was completed.
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation.

• The agency was apprised the evaluation shall consistently show
documentation of interviews with all household members, inclusive of each
foster parent.
R400.12327(5)(d) Special evaluation.
• The agency was apprised the analysis section of the special evaluation report
has to clearly show how the worker arrived at the findings of facts, and not
just state "violation established, which is the documentation in the conclusion
section.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
This incident related to a complaint received against a foster home on
7/26/2023.The complaint alleged that the foster father had a video of himself
sexually maltreating his 13-year-old adoptive son. Additionally, that the foster
father inappropriately touched the private parts of his 11year old adoptive son.
During the investigation the foster parent denied the allegations. During interviews
with both children by the agency worker, as well as via Kids-Talk interviews, the
children reported inappropriate sexual maltreatment by the foster father. The
children were removed from the home. The agency found the foster parent in
violation of the foster parent reporting rule because the foster parent did not report
his arrest related to the allegation. The agency also found the foster parent in
violation of the applicant/license qualification rule, based on the evidence at hand.
Revocation of the foster parent’s foster home license was recommended.
The agency appeared to have acted appropriately in this incident. The agency
adhered to all departmental requirements.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s Interim inspection where it
received the following rule and policy violations:
• R400.12212(2)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12306(4) Application request.

• R400.12324(8) Reevaluation.
• R300.12413(1)(c) (ii) Medical and dental policy.
• ISEP 4.22 MIASCWIS (Commitment 22).
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, Types, And Time frames.
Supervisor Approval.
• FOM 722-8D Treatment plan. Agreement and signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of Children
under supervision of MDHHS.
As it relates to the agency’s efforts to achieve this corrective action plan, the
agency provided documentation showing its use of spreadsheets to track
performance evaluations, medical health screens, and initial medical passport due
dates for submission of that document to the caregivers. Not all of these tools
indicated success. Other actions indicated in the corrective action plan, such as
utilization of a licensing upload checklist, routing of service plans within seven days,
and trauma screening completions at the time of the five-day case transfer
conference between children protective services and foster care were items shown
by way of the file reviews. Additional documents provided by the agency to aid in
showing its compliance to the corrective action plan were samples of email
reminders to staff related to treatment plan signature due dates and MISACWIS
document upload day reminders; a licensing team meeting agenda for 7/18/2023,
and sample calendar reminders by foster care supervisors/administration related to
performance evaluation due dates, social work contact training, quarterly and
management team meetings; and sample calendar reminders by licensing
supervisors to staff related to foster parent licensure renewal due dates, 45-day
letters due dates; and foster parent orientation dates.
The agency’s efforts to complete this corrective action resulted in some progress in
a few areas, but the agency was not totally successful with all, as indicated by the
repeat violations indicated in this report. Additionally, as seen in this report the
agency’s rule non-compliance in various areas increased from the previous year.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2023C0000332.
The complaint was received on 3/17/2023 and it alleged the agency placed a foster
youth in a non-legal placement and incorrectly added the placement in the
MISACWIS system as an unlicensed relative, which was inaccurate. During the
special investigation the agency was found in violation of rule R400.12404(1) due to
the agency’s placement of the child into a fictive kin placement on 6/24/2022 when
it did not receive approval from the court to do so until 8/10/2022. The agency has
implemented this corrective action plan by way of uploading the court order from
the court on that placement, creation of a spread sheet to track such
cases/placements, and reminders to staff on kinship placement requirements. The
agency had not had additional placements of this type at the time of review, so
sample home studies and referrals to kinship staff by workers, and monitoring of
needs requires later assessment.

Chief Administrator Assessment
A chief administrator’s report was received dated 11/15/2023. Aside from my
advisement to the chief administrator to show the actual number of disrupted and
unplanned removal within the report, there were no noted concerns for this
document.
Financial Overview
Not applicable. This is a Department of Health and Human Services child welfare
foster care program.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Aside from my discussion with the chief administrator, four section managers, and
two licensing supervisors during the entrance conference, I interviewed one foster
care supervisor, one licensing worker and one foster care worker. The staff did not
report notable concerns or issues.
Youth interviews were not applicable. The agency does not have youths in
independent living placements.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not reveal any noted concerns or safety issues.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had three safety alerts during this licensing inspection period:
Concern:
The first safety alert was received on 10/10/2023 related to an unlicensed relative’s
home not having an operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy and/or
near all sleeping areas. The unlicensed relative’s home did not have a smoke
detector in the basement.
Resolution:
The agency provided the unlicensed relative smoke alarms for the basement level of
the home on 10/11/2023. Photos showing the installation of all three devices were
provided.
Concern:
The second safety alert was received on 10/10/2023 related to a foster home not
having an operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy and/or near all
sleeping areas. The foster home did not have a smoke detector on the main level of
the home.
Resolution:
On 10/11/2023, the licensing worker took a smoke detector to the foster home and
ensured that it was appropriately installed. A photo showing the installation of the
smoke detector was provided.

Concern:
The third safety alert was received on 10/25/2023 related to a foster home not
having an operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy. A smoke detector
was not observed in the basement of the home; and one of the smoke detectors on
the main level was beeping and needed to be replaced.
Resolution
The agency’s licensing worker went to the foster home with two new smoke
detectors on 10/26/2023. The worker replaced the smoke detector in the living room
and installed a smoke detector in the basement. Photos were provided showing the
installation of both devices.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
December 11, 2023
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 12, 2023
_____________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
